headline: UBiome Interim CEO to Leave Company
summary: John Rakow is leaving after two months as interim chief executive as the lab-testing startup shakes up its leadership for the second time since a federal investigation into its billing practices became public two months ago.

headline: 10 Killed in Dallas-Area Small-Plane Crash
summary: Ten people were killed when a small airplane crashed into a hangar while taking off from a Dallas-area airport Sunday morning, a spokeswoman for the town of Addison, Texas, said.

headline: Trump’s Twitter Invitation to Kim Set Off 24-Hour Scramble
summary: President Trump surprised his own advisers when he offered on Twitter to “say Hello(?)!” to North Korea’s Kim Jong Un on the border between North and South Korea, setting into motion a 24-hour scramble to prepare for a possible meeting.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for edition of July 1, 2019

headline: Durant, Irving Pick the Nets
summary: The two NBA stars are coming to New York to play for the Nets, not the Knicks, as free agency begins with a frenzy of signings on Sunday night.

headline: New OPEC-Russia Pact on Oil Cuts Could Last Well Into 2020
summary: OPEC and its Russia-led allies are likely to extend by nine months their deal to cut output, a sign that some major crude-producing countries are concerned about the possibility of shrinking demand.

headline: New York Pride March Attracts Big Crowds
summary: Throngs of spectators lined the route of the NYC Pride March, the LGBTQ community’s annual push for equality, as it commemorated the 50th anniversary of the uprising at Greenwich Village’s Stonewall Inn.

headline: Progressive Groups Eye New York Incumbents to Challenge
summary: Progressive groups that propelled insurgent candidate Tiffany Cabán to finish ahead in the race to become Queens district attorney are already eyeing their next political targets.

headline: Throngs Gather for New York Pride March
summary: The NYC Pride March on Sunday drew enormous crowds to an event that commemorated the 50th anniversary of the uprising at Greenwich Village’s Stonewall Inn, considered a defining moment in the gay-rights movement.

headline: New Jersey Passes Budget, Avoids a Government Shutdown
summary: New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy signed a $38.7 billion state budget, despite the legislature’s denial of some of his key priorities, averting a government shutdown that would have started Monday.

headline: The Trump Doctrine
summary: With this President, the diplomacy is always personal.

headline: Key Dates in the U.S.-China Trade Conflict
summary: Washington and Beijing have been exchanging levies and threats for more than a year in their continuing trade dispute.

headline: Is That Bacon Merely Fakin’?
summary: As veggie alternatives gain ground, farmers try to seize the language.

headline: Australian Rugby Star’s Anti-Gay Post Exposes Fault Lines
summary: The firing of one of Australia’s best-known sports stars for saying gay people are headed for hell has exposed social fault lines and sparked debate about what constitutes religious expression.

headline: Trade Truce a Relief to Markets—For Now
summary: Stocks and other risky assets are likely to enjoy a brief rally after the emergence of a trade truce over the weekend, though concerns about the U.S. and China’s long-term relationship and the path of interest rates could keep a lid on any gains.

headline: Church, School and the Supreme Court
summary: The Justices finally tee up a state Blaine Amendment for review.

headline: Oil-Field Services Company Weatherford to File for Bankruptcy
summary: Weatherford International, a Swiss-based oil-field services company, said it would file for bankruptcy protection after bondholders approved a restructuring agreement that will reduce its total debt by about 70%.

headline: Biotech Startup Century Therapeutics Lands $250 Million in Venture Financing
summary: Corporate and venture-capital investors are funneling $250 million into startup Century Therapeutics to finance an effort to cure cancers through a new type of cellular therapy.

headline: Was ‘Bridgegate’ Criminal, or Just Dirty Politics?
summary: By agreeing to hear the New Jersey case about traffic as political payback, the Supreme Court might be aiming to limit prosecutors’ ability to bring charges against officials without clear bribery or kickback schemes.

headline: Is the Supreme Court’s Job to Defer?
summary: Kagan and Gorsuch clash over separation of powers and the right method of interpreting regulations.

headline: INF Treaty Defenders Raise the Risk of Nuclear War
summary: A dangerous plan to ban research and development of intermediate-range conventional weapons.

headline: An Underdog Challenges Erdogan
summary: The president, a former Istanbul mayor, has a rival in the current one.

headline: Mrs. Swalwell May Still Be Undecided
summary: I admire people who had the good sense not to watch last week’s debates. I wasn’t among them.

headline: Kill Section 230, You Kill the Internet
summary: Leave Big Tech intact and free to moderate content—but make the rules transparent.

headline: Dialogue With Maduro Is a Trap
summary: Cuba is employing its age-old tricks in an effort to keep the dictator in power.

headline: My Customers Don’t Pay Trump’s Tariffs
summary: We negotiated lower prices from Chinese factories instead.

headline: ‘Old Whigs’ Review: Rejecting the Extremes
summary: Today’s overheated politics make prudent statesmanship seem hopelessly distant, but our future may depend on it—yet again.

headline: As Stocks Hover Near Records, Growth Worries Linger
summary: Stocks are flirting with records again, but many investors are struggling to discern how much longer the bull market can continue.

headline: Economy Week Ahead: International Trade, Manufacturing, Jobs
summary: In the week ahead, the U.S. will see fresh manufacturing, trade and employment data.

headline: England Entertains Thoughts of World Cup Victory
summary: England hasn’t been ready to win much of anything in soccer over half a century. Now the manager of the women’s national team, Phil Neville, knows what he has: a powerhouse in the making.

headline: Apartment Demand Hits Five-Year High
summary: Demand for rental apartments reached a five-year high this spring, spurred by new household formation and lagging home sales.

headline: Blinder Risk-Assessment Approach Is Mistaken
summary: Before the last financial crisis, bank regulators and the SEC had plenty of power to stop the increase in leverage occurring among the largest banks, which seriously destabilized the industry. They chose not to.

headline: Qatar’s Banks Are No Haven for Terrorists
summary: Qatar can state for certain that our financial system is not being used by those who support terrorism.

headline: Prof. Feldstein and Apple and Orange Prices
summary: When apples go up in price (because of rising costs to producers, transporters, retailers, etc.) and people switch to oranges, the increased demand for oranges causes the price of oranges to rise.

headline: No Need to Look Abroad for Monetary Policy Errors
summary: The anemic economic growth during the current recovery spurred the Ben Bernanke and Janet Yellen Feds to stimulate economic growth by keeping its policy rate at zero for six-and-a-half years.

headline: Systems Like WinRed Must First Seek to Do No Harm
summary: For the past month, however, my email has been inundated with solicitations from unknown Republican candidates from all over the country. All seem to use one of about four standard formats.

headline: Trump’s North Korea Moment Started With a Tweet, Ended With a Step
summary: President Trump’s spontaneous meeting with North Korea’s Kim Jong Un inside the DMZ produced the U.S. presidency’s first steps into the isolated regime.

headline: Even $1 Trillion Can’t Make the World a Better Place
summary: Norway’s large sovereign-wealth fund reversed its ethical ban on owning shares in five companies after they changed their ways. But the cause and effect is hard to discern.

headline: Democrats Take Issue With Trump’s Overseas Meetings
summary: Democratic 2020 candidates criticized President Trump over issues ranging from nuclear talks with North Korea to Mr. Trump’s making light, in an appearance with Russian President Vladimir Putin, of interference in U.S. elections.

headline: Drink Makers Seek More Recycled Plastic
summary: Beverage companies aiming to use more recycled plastic in their packaging are facing a shortage of discarded containers from recycling programs.

headline: Gray Wave Gives Slow-Growing World a Boost
summary: In advanced economies, a growing share of retirement-age workers are staying on the job, countering the drag of demographics.

headline: U.S. Deals Lead the Way as Rest of the World Lags Behind
summary: A flurry of mergers and big initial public offerings in the U.S. make it the runaway success story in global deal making, standing in contrast to sluggish activity in Europe and Asia.

headline: Palestinian Authority Targets Bahrain Conference Attendees
summary: The Palestinian Authority has targeted local businessmen who participated in a U.S.-led economic conference in Bahrain last week centered on improving the Palestinian economy, arresting one attendee and trying to detain another.

headline: Manhattan Buyers Rush to Beat New Mansion Tax
summary: A surge of closings isn’t enough to offset weakening apartment sales in the second quarter, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis of city property sales.

headline: This Fund Is Riding Bitcoin to Top
summary: Bitcoin is booming again. One of the biggest beneficiaries is Grayscale Bitcoin Trust, a fund that provides everyday investors with access to the world’s most popular cryptocurrency.

headline: Bitcoin’s Surge Leaves Smaller Digital Currencies in the Dust
summary: One key difference between this year’s bitcoin climb and the last big rally is what has happened to other cryptocurrencies: they haven’t done as well.

headline: The Problem With ‘Harry Potter: Wizards Unite’
summary: Niantic’s new augmented-reality game, a successor to “Pokémon Go,” brings Harry Potter wizardry to your world, but it doesn’t feel enough like a real Potter adventure.

headline: Oil Prices Caught Between Slower Growth and Mideast Turmoil
summary: Oil prices have been on a bumpy ride the past few months, with sagging demand and geopolitical tensions vying for supremacy over crude’s direction.

headline: Women’s Tennis Has a New No. 1. But for How Long?
summary: Ashleigh Barty has taken over the top spot and is a favorite at Wimbledon. But there’s different pressure when a player is expected to win.

headline: Scooter Braun Makes $300 Million Deal for Big Machine Records
summary: Pop-music talent manager Scooter Braun agreed to buy Big Machine Label Group for more than $300 million, a deal the largely country-music record label sees helping it plug into pop music’s streaming landscape.

headline: How ‘Stranger Things’ Whipped Up ’80s Fever
summary: ‘Stranger Things,’ returning to Netflix July 4, has stoked ’80s nostalgia even among viewers born long after the decade of scrunchies and shopping malls.

headline: How Tennis Star Reilly Opelka Bounced Back From Injury
summary: Reilly Opelka is 21 years old—and almost 7 feet tall. Here’s the exercise regimen he followed after being sidelined by injuries.

headline: New Thinking Challenges the Stigma Over ‘Shock Therapy’
summary: Although memory loss remains a risk, doctors say electroconvulsive therapy can be an important tool for patients with severe depression.

headline: ECB’s Draghi Grows Bolder as His Tenure Nears End
summary: Mario Draghi is teeing up some of the boldest policy moves of his eight-year term as European Central Bank president only four months before he steps down, potentially binding the hands of his successor for years.

headline: Walmart Turns to VR to Pick Middle Managers
summary: The country’s largest employer is using a VR skills assessment as part of the selection process to find new middle managers, hoping to limit inherent bias in hiring decisions, increase diversity and reduce turnover in a tight labor market.

headline: G-20 Tells Social-Media Operators to Step Up Efforts Against Terrorist Content
summary: The U.S. joined other major nations in calling for social-media companies to crack down on violent terrorist content online, an apparent easing of Washington’s concerns about internet censorship.

headline: Trump Leaves Huawei’s South Korean Suppliers Hanging
summary: In a speech to South Korea’s largest conglomerates after he eased the toughest U.S. measures against Huawei, President Trump provided no direction on how they should proceed with the Chinese tech giant.

headline: Fed Officials Are Expected to Find Little to Boost Outlook From Trade Truce
summary: An agreement between President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping to resume trade negotiations avoids further deterioration in the economic outlook for now, but it does little to clear the fog of uncertainty weighing on global trade and investment.

headline: Trump Steps Into North Korea as Two Sides Agree to Restart Nuclear Talks
summary: President Trump said after stepping into North Korea that the U.S. and the North had agreed to designate nuclear negotiating teams to begin work in the coming weeks, an unexpected burst of diplomacy resulting from an impromptu meeting with the North’s leader, Kim Jong Un.

headline: For MLB’s Debut in Europe, an Unusual Yankees-Red Sox Series
summary: Major League Baseball came to London this weekend to introduce the sport to the U.K. market. The Yankees and Red Sox delivered a supercharged interpretation of baseball, with both games exceeding four hours.

headline: U.S.-China Trade Talks Are Back On but Obstacles Remain
summary: President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping managed to get troubled talks back on track, but an even tougher job lies ahead: appeasing factions within their own governments demanding they give no quarter.

headline: At Purdue Pharma, Business Slumps as Opioid Lawsuits Mount
summary: OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma is struggling with slumping sales, a shrinking workforce and restructuring problems as it battles lawsuits related to the opioid crisis.

headline: Germany Scorned Air Conditioning—Then Came the Heat Wave
summary: America’s fondness for artificially chilled air was long viewed as wasteful, unnatural and wimpy, but record temperatures have some Germans rethinking.

headline: EU, Mercosur Deal Faces Hurdles on Two Continents
summary: It took 20 years of on-and-off talks to reach a deal Friday on a trade pact between the European Union and four South American nations. Winning implementation could take years, with environmentalists and trade unions making final approval a challenge.

headline: In Arizona Desert, Elite Border Patrol Unit Responds to Desperate Cases
summary: Of the many ways migrants end up in Border Patrol custody, getting picked up by the BORSTAR unit is among the most desperate. The trained EMTs rescue people who are stranded in the mountains, caught in swift moving water, in medical need, or who dial 911, a call people tend to make only in the most dire state.

headline: Jony Ive Is Leaving Apple, but His Departure Began Long Ago
summary: Apple’s design chief helped create some of the world’s best-known products, but grew distant from leadership, as the company shifted its focus to operations under CEO Tim Cook.
